Title: PLEASE MAKE ANOTHER GAME  Pros: - Metroid - Very fun such wow - Runs very smooth - Difficulty is just right, normal is normal and hard is hard and difficulty curve in both modes are just right - Fast paced  Cons: - EDIT: Final boss too easy on Hard difficulty, 2nd and 3rd took my 45 mins and final boss was 5 mins - It ends - No support for multiple save files (I need 3: Normal, Hard, Co-op with my gf), you can still copy and rename the save files etc - I guess Online co-op would be really hard to pull off because how fast this game is, it would bring the sync hell, but still...  Missing: - (Assumption) Ability to create challenge levels within workshop  I defeated first 3 major bosses in Hard recently, most fun boss battles I ever had I'm not a very good gamer, I fail at MANY games I have to play most games on Easy and on some games even that doesn't help, but even I can progress at Hard difficulty in this game so people saying difficulty is unfair are probably trolls

Awesome game. Tons of fun.  Controls are tight and responsive. Move list is huge combos are satisfying. Levels are expansive and fun to play.  The puzzle rooms are a joy, not a burden.  This is about as good as it gets folks.  I'm not even a fan of the whole Mexican Luchador theme, and still I couldn't put this down. Not knowing what the spanish words meant was kind of a bummer, but added to the overall feel of playing a Mexican game.  Be prepared to laugh every 30 minutes or so. Not the '*chuckle chuckle* I see what you did there' kind of laugh, but the genuine laugh out loud.  This game includes throw backs to more old school platformers than I can list here. I won't spoil the surprise by listing any, but if you like platformers and have played them NES to current day, you will recognize so many things.  for instance I noticed nearly every screen of an entire section of the game being a copy from an older platformer game. You might think that would be a negative, but to me it was simply a joy.  I could go on and on, but suffice to say this game is awesome.  Buy it.
Awesome and Fun Metroidvania with Luchadores!

A+ geargate game. Fun combat, fun/challenging platforming, neat artstyle, and really funny writing. Occassional stunlockage gets annoying, and some of the bosses are just a little bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but otherwise just a really great game. Kinda short though, only 13 hours to 100% it.
this is my type of game :)
this game is quite fun

A great Metroidvania style game. The challenge rooms near the end can make you redo them multiple times to get gold ranking. The only drawback I can say is there is a learning curve to pull off a chain of combos.

Hilarious, ridiculous, and crazy fun. Guacamelee is what you get when you implement Super Smash Bros-esque controls in a Metroidvania game. I played through the whole game co-op with a friend in one sitting, and it was fantastic. The main quest is short, but there are a lot of sidequests and collectibles scattered here and there to keep you entertained.  Praises: + Comedic gold. The characters and dialogue are pretty ridiculous, and there are a plethora of references to internet memes/jokes. + Simplistic art style, vibrant colors, and smooth animations. What's especially nice is the strong visual contrast between the world of the living and the world of the dead. + Challenging puzzles, both in solving and executing. + A pretty steady learning curve. By the end of the game, you have a lot of different moves and abilities at your disposal, but they are presented to you one by one throughout the course of the whole game so you aren't overwhelmed. + Two-player co-op is drop-in/drop-out style; great for old-fashioned 'come over and play this game with me' fun.  Criticisms: - A controller is basically a requirement to play. Trying to play with keyboard feels awkward, and you have less precise control of your throws (limited to the 8 directions of WASD as opposed to the full 360-degree control of a thumbstick) - Many of the level designs are far too difficult for both players to coordinate. Most of the time, it was much quicker and easier for one player to turn themselves into a bubble so the other could navigate the level. - I personally don't see this as a huge issue, but an online co-op option would be nice.  All in all, Guacamelee is a fantastic beat-em-up game that will keep you laughing behind your luchador mask.

An excellent platformer/beat-em-up game with a vivid artstyle and catchy electro/mariachi soundtrack. The fighting is very fluid in the game, with new moves introduced as it progresses and makes platforming a lot more fun to do as well.  One word of warning though: there are quite a few instances of bright flashing colours appearing when you get powerups or new moves, so you might want to beware if you have epilepsy or previous experiences with seizures.

I don't normally play Metroidvania games, but I decided to pick this up. Turned out to be one of the better games I've played. The controls are very responsive and the moveset feels natural. Each special move serves its purpose, both in combat and while platforming. The music and art style fit great with the rest of the game and the all the background references to other games are just enough without going overboard. Some of the boss fights seem a little unfair at first (especially on Hard Mode), but after paying attention to the fight, you start to understand what to do - just challenging enough. All in all, this was a really fun game, though a bit short. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun game with some challenge. Note to new players: learn the importance of dodging, you'll need it.

This is a fun platformer/beat-em-up with a neat graphical style. Gameplay-wise it's nothing you haven't played 1000 times, but it has a lot of charm. I like that you can choose a male or female character, and there are several skins you can unlock for them. The game's overall theme is a caricature of Mexican culture, which some may find to be racist. I won't debate that either way, but I'd put it at about the same level as Speedy Gonzales cartoons - if you found those offensive, then maybe you should give this game a pass. Possible racial implications aside, it's a fun action game. Make sure you have a controller, as some of the moves are difficult to pull off with a keyboard.
Fantastic platformer.
COME ON AND JAM  AND WELCOME TO THE SLAM

Super fun game with lots of extra content and varied gameplay. As someone who normally doesn't enjoy beat-em-up style combat, I was surprised by how strategic it ended up being, and found myself looking forward to future enemy encounters. As someome who normally does enjoy indie platformers, this game stepped it up with Metroidvania-style levels that forced you to use not only jumping skills, but combat moves and speical abilities in order to progress. A great game all around, and one that I would definitely reccomend to anyone looking for either a modern or classic platformer/beat-em-up.

I want to like Guacamelee. I really do. The Developers did almost everything right. The art style, animations, soundtrack, sound effects, and humor are all top notch. But there are a couple of major problems that hold this game back. The lesser of the two evils is the level design. For the most part, the side puzzles are clever, and the rewards for completing them make them feel worth the effort. However, I can't say the same for the required puzzles.   Much of the later half of the game is vertically oriented, and eventually the game seems to degenerate into a very sloppy platformer. There are few things more frustrating than almost making it to the top of a series of very tiny platforms, only to have one of the many enemies that have started chasing you (as there's no room to fight them) hit you, resulting in knockback the likes of which hasn't been seen since the original NES Castlevania games, and send you all the way back down to the bottom.  This brings me to the more dire of the game's issues: the controls. As another reviewer mentioned, the game starts off with very tight, responsive, and just generally great controls. But as your move pool increases, you increasingly feel like you're in the game. And by that, I mean that it feels like you're wrestling your controller. There are a pretty decent amount of moves at your disposal by the end of the game, and as which move you use depends on which direction you're moving the control stick, pulling off the right move while moving and trying to dodge can be a hassle.  Also, a quick, slightly-spoilery, albeit non-specific complaint about the story:    The endings (yes, both of them) are huge letdowns. Especially after the journey to reach them.    And now for the good parts:  Despite my criticisms, the first half of the game is one of the best metroidvania games I've seen in a long time. The amount of hidden collectibles is incredible, and as I've stated before, the optional puzzles are incredible! And it has the benefit of having something that very, very few PC games seem to include these days: local multiplayer. With steam increasingly pushing Big Picture mode and couch gaming on PCs, Guacamelee is finally giving those of us PC gamers with a social life something we've been longing for for a very long time: a game we can play with friends in the same room (without forcing them to drag their rigs over to our houses). Playing with a friend can reduce the frustration caused by the aforementioned problems, and I'll be honest, it's just plain fun!  Overall, despite the control and occasional level design issues, the game is worth playing, especially if it's on sale, and you've got someone to play it with! I might not recommend it at full price, but it's definitly an enjoyable experience.

Well that's a good game. It's challenging, hard and unforgiving where it needs to be, has stunning vibrant colorful awesome graphics that entwine smoothly with the story; the control scheme is broad and a little confusing at times, but acceptable. Maybe a bit short (I've almost finished it in about 10 hours, with every side quest apart from the really long ones) and with a really little replay value, but a great experience nonetheless. 85/100

This game reminded me of the side scrollers of old including how hard it was. Very fun game with lots of interesting enemies. The final boss was by far the most annoying/rewarding boss to defeat. I would recommend this game to anyone that grew up in the 80's and early 90's and were used to hard side scrollers such as mega man.

Just finished this game last night and I have to say I really enjoyed it. Coming off of Dust: An Elysian Tail before this, both of these games were great MetroidVania-style games, both felt different while not straying too far off the path.  - Environment on this game is a little sillier without making it feel stupid - Love the cartoon-like art style Makes the characters actions and story feel more believable. - Combat system is easy to pick up, and while they can show you many combos with the moves you learn throughout the game, I was able to kind of create my own and play in the action my way, in a sense. - While I don't feel that this game has a lot of replayability, there is quite a bit to do while you are playing it and you can beat the game and go back and finish it if you are up to the challenges. - Some of the platforming is HARD AS HELL... and I loved it! It is one of things that made me come back for more. - Not to forget, there are little Easter Eggs everywhere, paying homage to great game titles and internet memes.  If you like games like Metroid and Castlevania, this is one to pick up, I definitely recommend it.

This is where the reviews really help; I saw this game, but wasn't sure about it. Then, I read the reviews and most were positive. This is a side-scrolling game that is a lot of fun to play. The graphics are different, but beautiful and give the game its own style. I'm a mouse and keyboard player, but after playing about five hours decided to try an xbox controller as it was recommended. The controller definitely made a difference by making the moves in the game easier to input. I would recommend this game as it has a great art style, has some great platforming puzzles to get through, and is a lot of fun to play.
Awesome platformer that plays like Super Metroid. Funny references to other games. Easy to play with a controller. Grab this game on a sale, and you will actually play it =P

Brawl your way through the realm of the living and the dead to try and save the love of your life or is that afterlife!  A wonderful brawler with interesting special attacks, great costumes and skills to buy as well as beautiful artwork. The story line allows you to visit new areas while at the same time helping you to unlock skills, find side quests and see the world in two different ways as you build up to the day of the dead.  Even as an unexperienced player to these games i found it fun and possible to play even if a little more challenging. It also has challenges for the more serious player with the different levels and puzzle rooms that you need to lucho through.   A beautifully made game that is well worth a play! :D

This is the most Mexican game you'll ever find, despite being made in Canada. It's a great one; the controls are tight, the difficulty felt just right, the visuals are stylish and the world is filled with subtle references to other games and internet memes. If you're remotely interested in platformers, definitely go for this one. My only regret with it is having waited half-a-year after purchasing it on sale.
Fun platofmer with lots of luchador action
is a very nice game, art style and gameplay. Level design can be improve a little bit, give some more challenge to player.
This game is really great. Vibrant Day of the Dead themed 'Metroidvania' with a fantastic combat system.

So when I started considering whether I should recommend this game or not, I realized just how split my opinion on this game is. While I enjoyed most of it, there was a huge spike in difficulty at around the 4-5 hour mark (well, 4-5 hour mark for myself) whereas the enemies weren't the issue - it was the platforming. There was a point when everything so far had been smooth sailing when it came to the platforming and suddenly the flow came to a stop because I had to perform the platforming only to fail - but mainly just to see what's ahead. And so I had to pause the game and think about how to proceed. It really halted my enjoyment because... I actually had to stop playing for a minute or so every once in a while. And it was boring. With that being said, the platforming then takes a huge dip in difficulty as well, when you gain a couple more powers that really improve the flow again. Just know that there's that one section which will probably make you stop... and think.  I must say though that I was pleasently surprised by how tight the controls felt - on a keyboard. Normally, platformer games tend to be rather clunky and nearly unplayable on keyboards but Guacamelee nailed it, in my opinion. And it's not just the controls for general movement. Even the controls for fighting felt incredibly responsive and I had no issues whatsoever pulling off some rather effective combos (though do keep in mind that I'm terrible at pulling off combos in every game, ever...) So yeah, the controls really felt good and if the fact that you haven't got a gamepad puts you off, then I'll tell you right now: 'Don't worry about it, brah, 'sall good.'  The story is very cute. The characters are very interesting. Though one of the villains did leave me a bit disappointed since you had very little interaction with him beyond the occasional warning and I feel like a bit more backstory would've solved that problem. I would also say that there's another character who gets you out of a rather tight spot who I would've liked to see more of - mainly because when I found out who he is, I chuckled and imagined some rather interesting future interactions.  With all that said, I feel like this game is worth a playthrough. I didn't really feel compelled to play through it again on hard mode nor to get the alternate ending (though that's mainly because I imagine that I'd have too hard of a time obtaining the final 2-3 orbs), but definitely worth that one playthrough. That's all for me, folks.  Sincerely, Crayt

A side-scrolling, platform beat-em-up with a lucha libre theme and a mariachi soundtrack.  That's a winning combo in my book.  This game is a hell of a lot of fun and the alternative skins that the community has made just top everything off.

Great level design, combat, and soundtrack. Although, I have no idea why the developers thought that inserting 'le totally epic maymays' into this game would benefit or enhance the game-player's experience, as the 'memes' mostly distracted me and appeared extremely out of place. Reddit humor aside, Guacamelee is still a fun metroidvania-style game that deserves a playthrough.
You can wrestle chickens in this game.
Great game. Anyone who grew up with a Super Nintendo owes it to himself to play this game.
The only metroidvania game on steam that isn't a dime-a-dozen clone
Great game
Beside the boring intro this is an amazing game! Great art, good humor, fun gameplay. You get to suplex esqueletos! What more could you want?
A totally awesome game with lots of love and humor in it! The force is strong with this one!

You're a tequila farmer who must save the president's daughter from a villain worse than the devil. You die and come back from the dead as a masked luchador (like any normal tequila farmer) ready to save the day. This is a fun platformer with a brawler twist that encourages exploration. You'll notice many references to video games and even get a good laugh or two from this fun and engaging title. After you beat it, you'll have the option to play on hard mode (which is legitimately hard). There's also the inferno: a series of challenges that test your skill at the game.  Steamworks is a nice touch and it lets you use custom skins for your character. There's something gratifying about playing as Johnny Bravo. There are many skins and more to come in the workshop. The game also features local co-op. You can play with a buddy if you have a pair of controllers and a tv to hook up to.  I got this game on sale at the humble indie store. If you have some extra cash and are looking for a good time, I would definitely recommend this one.

Oh my god, this game is amazing. I cannot count the bazillion references the devs managed to smuggle into the game. But that's just one of many things that makes clear how much effort and love has been put into the game. The game features a unique story plus awesome artwork. Soundtrack is a bit repetitive but high-quality - it's just that you have be open for the hardcore-mexican audio experience. Difficulty is above-average but way below Super Meat Boy - it's always fair and will never cost you too much nerves. And the general game style is Castlevania/Super Metroid, i.e. 2D RPG jump'n'run action sidescroller, without too much RPG. It's been on humble bundle the third time as of writing for a reason.
A great game! I got it on Steam sale and haven't stopped playing it!
is a really really good game, i havent played it that much, but i love al de internet references like de memes and the way they make tribute to another game characters in a luchador form
An amazing, colorful, funny and entertaining metroidvania style game with a lot of replay value.

This game is a lot of fun, and the writing is silly. Some of the optional/secret platforming sections are really difficult. As such this game made me feel bad about myself and my ability to play games. I highly reccommend it.

I'm surprised this game isn't more popular. Or maybe it's just my Metroidvania obssession that is telling me it should be more popular.  This game isn't really anything too different. It's your standard Metroidvania game with similar obstacles, powerups, and layout, only everything is a joke. Goat Jump? Goat Run? Goat Fly? These are your powerups, which you get from a goat, obviously.  What really stands this game out from the rest is it's art style, music, and sense of humor. The combat system is fun once you get the repetitive nature of keeping your combo up and learn all of the special moves and grapples.  There's also a ton of hidden things to find (including a handful of references to other games/movies) and a few challenge areas, just to take that silly edge off and remind you this game can be challenging.  All in all, a short fun little game that you will highly enjoy over a weekend.

I bought this game during the Steam Holiday Sale 2013 and I have to say that it is pretty freaking awesome. I definitely is a play on Metroid. You learn new abilities from Metroid-looking alters that are hidden in secret areas. There are tons of hidden areas in the game only reachable with your newly learned abilities. There is a good learning curve too: when you progress through the game they add new layers of difficulty that make the game much more difficult. There are harder enemies, harder jumping mechanics (you jump a LOT in this game), and harder bosses to kill. This a 2D masterpiece too with its own personality. I highly suggest picking this up if you're a Metroid fan. DO IT.

Metroidvanias are a dime a dozen. Metroidvanias with this kind of charm, attention to detail, and intricate fighting system are decidedly NOT a dime a dozen. This is a short review: Get it. You won't regret it.
Try this salsa flavored Metroidvania style game. Pure awesomeness!
Very fun platformer. Well balanced difficulty throughout the game. Lots of hidden things to find and awesome graphical theme.  Well worth the time and money!

This game was among only a few that was able to pry me from multiplayer-only games. It's a great platformer, and easy to pick up and play casually. Has a lot of great dialogue, most of it just being funny. It's challenging enough to make it frustrating at times (in a good way), but rewarding all in the same. Great game.
If you have ever enjoyed a Metroid or Castlevania game, you'll love this one. All around great and funny game.

Guacamelee is a really colourful and funny 2D platformer that engages me with its rapid and never dull combat gameplay.   It portrays a very simple storyline with many interesting elements inside. I bought this game off steam after reading through the reviews and recommendations and would like to share my own as I really love this game.  If you are looking for simple games like Mario, then you will be in for a shock. Platforming through the map requires frequent button mashing and quick thinking. It is easy to get frustrated initially due to the difficulty of navigating through the map, just for 1 simple treasure. However, once you get the hang of it, you would want to challenge yourself more!  Also, the combat system is really interesting. Just when you thought that the enemies are repetitive, you get shields on them which only certain moves can break them. You get enemies which you have to switch dimension to attack. You have to dodge, jump and wack your way through some stages.   I really love this game a lot and would certainly recommend it to everyone. The story is wackily simple with interesting characters like a GOAT, who teaches you moves, enormous chickens, skeletons and also my fav flame face.   Check this game out and hopefully, you will find it fun too :)
Amazingly fun sidescroller beat-em-up! You have to pick this up!
Metroidvania-style game with a luchadore theme. The animation style works really well. Pro-click.
One of the best platformer/beat'em up games I've ever had the pleasure to play with.  A hidden diamond.
Do you have an Xbox controller or nah? Ok then

This is probably one of the more unusual games I've ever played, but definitely one of the more fun ones.  A beat 'em up thats simple to pick up yet difficult to master with the theme of a mexican luchador fighting the forces of the land of the dead is unique enough without the humor, the wonderful art design, the excellent animation, the clever puzzles, and about fifty video game in-jokes and counting.  I'd highly recommend this one. If nothing else just for the sheer fun of suplexing skeletons into bone dust.

Very good melee platformer in a clean and crisp Mexican art style centered around a hero who finally becomes a Luchador. The controls are tight, enemies are varied, and platforming is fun(especially once you start getting more powers and abilities). ive never really cared for Mexican/hispanic/w.e music, but this music is good and compliments the game perfectly. Recommended for any lover of platformers

One of the best platformers I've played in recent memories. There are times when you want to throw your controller, especially if you're trying to 100% the game (Tule Tree, Sierra Morena orb levels, I'm looking at you), but the games tight controllers and well thought out mechanics save it from being TOO frusterating. After getting 100% in normal mode, I was able to breeze through hard mode because all the challenges the game had to offer honed my skills.  If you like Metroid-vania platformers, you'll love Guacamelee. Spent 20+ hours in this game. Don't regret a single second of it.
Great game with some really cool easter eggs and things to notice. If you like luchadores,you will enjoy.
With incredibly smooth gameplay and comedic characters, this game is a joy!

The very definition of 'short but sweet'. This game is a mix of Metroidvania-style progression, beat 'em up combat (with a pretty deep combo system), and some pretty challenging puzzle-platforming.   As far as Metroidvania games go, this has to be one of my favourites; the pacing is excellent, combat is very fun, and the platforming is challenging without becoming excessively frustrating. Also, the game has a unique and striking art style, some great humor, and plenty of in-jokes and references to other games.  The game only took me around 5 hours to complete (without finding all the secrets), but I loved every minute. Highly recommended.

For a sale price, the game is great. At normal $15 price, you're getting somewhat ripped off. The game itself is short, as is the standard of these types of games. However, the level design is simple, and the secrets are very 'meh' at best.  Still, the music, gameplay, graphics, etc. all make for a fantastic package. It's just overpriced. Don't buy it for anything under 50% off.

This game is in a similar style as the side scrolling versions of Metroid, but with a more comical art styling. I absolutely loved Metroid, so I found this game perfect for me. While I was not as immersed in this game as Metroid, Guacamelee was waaaaay more fun!

A couple of the optional platforming segments are frustratingly difficult. Final boss fight was a bit of a letdown.  Overall a great game. I must admit, that I stopped playing after I put about an hour into a single screen, where I died over and over again.   Recommended if you are up for a real challenge. Guacamelee! is wrestling, sidescrolling platformer, high-paced, RPG/light, arcade fighting game packaged in a VERY colorful piñata shell. What I think is hilarious is that it's a Canadian dev team that made this game.  Starts off very easy, then gets somewhat difficult *solely* because sometimes it's hard to pull off the timing in the moves. There's a game mechanic in which you have to alternate between two different 'dimensions' which is difficult to explain without giving away too much of the story. Speaking of which, is pretty much on par with the Super Mario's story. Serviceable but not a lot of depth. BTW, you can morph into a chicken... Which is actually way more awesome than it sounds.  Game is a little too try-hard in terms of humor, but that's all subjective I suppose.  I can't stress enough, gameplay requires you to have lighting-fast reflexes or you will be forced to play through a lot of areas twice or more until you get it.  The level design is very good. It's challenging but not over the top. The game is pretty short if you're good at it. Which is good because it gets repetitive fairly soonish.  Everything is ULTRA colorful to the point where it kinda is an eyesore (people who get a new ability or challenger know what I'm talking about).  Music is amazing. Hope you like Spanish guitar and trumpet stabs. ;-)  8/10 Would luchador again.

I believe it'd be more fun with two people, as you could have someone to share in your agony. There is only local multiplayer, so you have to have a controller or two to play with a friend. I believe that what could make this game perfect is if it were to have online multiplayer.

Really enjoyed this game. The art style is great, controls are tight (using a controller, don't use a keboard), combat is fun and varied and the platforming is great. The puzzles are satisfying to solve (similar to super meat boy) but not too hard. Plenty of secrets and reasons to play through again.   Would recommend, andd I was pleasantly suprised as to how much it sucked me in.
awesome 2d platformer! controller is a must though

Played: Feb 2014 Pros: + Very comfortable controls that allow you to move intuitively (with controller) + Interesting visual style Cons: - Feels very short - Some enemies get very stale by the end - Story starts promising and ends nonsensical  This game bills itself as a “metroidvania” type platformer, and let’s face it: it pretty much is. Some areas are inaccessible until the correct special movement is unlocked, but ultimately there aren’t that many special moves, so many areas are open to you right from the start. You play as a luchador, so there won’t be any weapons to find, either; the few additional moves you can get in the game are all grapples (a move you can complete when smallish enemies have taken enough damage). The low number of moves contributes to the short feel of the game (probably about 8 hours for the first play-though), but man are they satisfying! Throwing a damaged enemy through a whole crowd of others and sending them flying like bowling pins should bring a grin to anybody who picks up this game.  On the other hand, there are only a few enemy types, and late-game difficulty increase consists largely of forcing you to take on more of them and introducing some unblockable types (read: fire-based attacks). As you get good, you’ll find that you can destroy many enemie types in 1-2 seconds, which is good, because otherwise you’d get really bored fighting the same 8-10 monsters.  The story starts out feeling epic, but pretty quickly you find you’re actually just rescuing Princess Peach from Bowser again. The boss minions of the main enemy have very crudely sketched reasons for working with him, nor is it ever clear just why your girlfriend was abducted in the first place. Furthermore, the devil is introduced as a character, then plays essentially zero role. Why introduce a pointless character you might ask? Maybe because the developers just wanted to… in any case this is not a game you should play because it “features elements of hispanic culture”-you won’t pick up any traditional lore at all.  Overall, the game is pretty darn good, and very memorable in some parts. You may find that you’ll get replay out of it if you go in for additional modes unlocked at the end of a run, but I’d try to get it for less than $10 if possible.

This game is a metroidvania combo-brawler with an extremely stylized mexican theme. I really enjoyed most aspects of this game. First I really want to draw attention to the game's amazing art and animation. They did not hold back one bit in committing to their art direction with wonderful color and shapes, and they also really paid off with dramatic mexican brass music. The game is often genuinely funny. So it's worth playing for those aspects alone. But it's also super fun to play.  Your ability to combo and throw enemies is pretty satisfying at the start of the game, and it's like 'Oh yeah I get it, I'm totally a luchador.' But it does a great job of building upon this with mobility and access powers. These take the form of fighting moves, as opposed to different energy beams (a la Metroid), and so at first they feel a little dry (as in, oh this block can only be broken with a certain punch I just got, but not my other punch... OK?). However, I really appreciate how well they compliment the game's melee-combat focus and double up as ways to dramatically improve your character's mobility. The game is most fun to play near the end, and you start to feel like a superhero luchador, which is just something I had never considered. My only complaint is that the combat is a bit unforgiving. It's hard, which is actually nice, but if you take a hit, it takes an excruciatingly long time to get back up, and on the last boss your timing has to just be incredibly perfect, so that got frustrating. I would definitely recommend Guacamelee. Also it has co-op. Go play it with your other friend who is also good at games.

One of the best new platfromers I've played, PERIOD.   Addictive gameplay with just the right amount of dificulty makes for an amazing play-through.  Controller highly recommended (2 if you wanna do the awesome local co-op)

I'm not someone who is intimitely familiar with platformers nor am I someone accustomed to the blissful feeling of completeing games. These were the two reasons why I felt like I had to play this after being seduced by the vivid colors and humerous writing, and I'm so glad I played Guacamelee.   Guacamelee brings me back to playing the old Metroid games on my Gameboy Advance, and the game knows it. Entire game mechanics are in-jokes which are a small part of the fantastic sense of humor of this title. The game takes place in technically an open world, where you can go to any area at any time, assuming you've unlocked the required move to reach the location. Despite being open, you will ALWAYS know exactly where to go, and the areas area small enough as to not feeling like any time is wasted traveling.   Unlike Metroid, Guacamelee features a fantastic brawling combat system which was deftly designed to grow in complexity at the perfect rate I was learning the game. Without being hindered by petty realism, you get to beat to staisfyingly beat up skeletons and throw them at their friends. Boss fights are almost always challenging but so incredibly satisfying when victorious.   The game is wrapped in a nice simple ~6 hour story where I always knew what my purpose was and what the stakes are. It's nothing very emotional but it succeded in giving the gameplay meaning.   All in all, Guacamelee was an incredibly satisfying game to complete and I'd recomend it to anyone interested in the genre of 2D platforming adventures.

Great art style, easy to pick up controls that are satisfying, a good challange by the end of the game and a good amount of secrets to find. Pretty great humour throughout and just a bunch of fun the play. Some of the endgame challanges will leave you in great pain through frustration would definitely reccommend.

Really fun metroidvania game. Give it a shot if you're feeling nostalgic for those.
Awesome game. If you like open-world platformers with some puzzles and lots of action, (e.g., super metroid, etc) you'll love Guacamelee.

I recommend this game if you are not a completionist.  + Fun combat + Humour + Atmosphere  - Bad and outright buggy controls. (I still press wrong keys sometimes. Also sometimes keypresses don't seem to register.) - It's completionist's hell. You have to revisit areas to find previously inaccessible chests[1]. Oh, and the disappearing platforms laugh at your misery.  [1]It's something I hate in video games. It it's a cheap attempt at artificially lenghtening the game. The graphic is colorful, the combos are very responsive and chains well together... and that's very important since you're required to chain a long combo to overcome some obstacles; but don't be afraid, the learning curve scales very well and all the most difficult parts are optional (expansion) or kinda optional (you can skip them if you don't care for the second ending). Guacmelee is a Metriodvania game where a skeleton devil kidnaps your girlfriend and you turn into a mighty Luchador with MIGHTY POWERS!!!! Basicly what I'm saying is this game isn't anything too special but that does not mean it's a bad game. The game has a beautiful Mexican art style that fill the screen with bright colors and is always a joy to look at. The side-scrolling beat-em up gameplay is very fun and introduces the player to many inventive and challenging puzzles along the way. As the story unfolds you collect new abilities after beating the many crazy boss characters (the most epic being the final boss) and it feels so rewarding to advance through the level. Now that I me addressed the good stuff about this game now for the bad stuff, Firstly I think that their could have been a little more varity in terms of enemy design because fighting the same enemies over and over can get a little redundent after a while. Other then that I highly recommend this game it has minor flaws but overall great game  I give it a 8.5/10   fun game

Guacamelee! Is based on four concepts:  - a Metroid-vania style of gameplay  - a semi-complicated fighting system  - luchadores portrayed in a cartoonish way  - jokes based on modern internet popculture  It seems that there is pretty much nothing you could dislike. Indeed the first half of the game was very enjoyable for me. Some dialogs are written really clever, and the gameplay itself is enough to keep you playing.  But then it all falls in to pieces. The more powers you unlock the more difficult it is to play on a computer keyboard. Soon it becomes unplayable and confusing... and this is the part when someone tells me I should use a gamepad (like the authors told me on the beginning of the game). Well I tried... I have three gamepads and none of them worked... oooohhhh.... it needs an XBOX controller?   So now I should pay because the authors are xbox fanboys or because they sold their souls to MS? Not a chance.  Releasing this game on a PC (an also Linux for god's sake!) is a mockery.  The keyboard and mouse are basic PC controllers , so a game released on WINDOWS/MAC/LINUX should be designed to work with them, or at least allow ANY gamepad to work with it on all operating systems it is available for (I use Linux all the time, and never once had a problem with any of my gamepads in a game that allowed them).  There is also something else, that happens after the first half of the game – all the creativity of the authors just vanish (and the jokes from the first half began to stop being funny in the context also):  „Erm... I don't know how to make this game actually, so... hmm... let's make it incredibly difficult, and fill it with irritating enemies, internet memes redrawn to look mexican and references to other games!”  Give me a break...  This is unfortunately a trend in modern indie games .  „Don't have an idea to make the gameplay interesting? Make it freakishly difficult.”  „Don't have an interesting story? Make it a parody. A parody with a very difficult gameplay!”  „We don't know how to balance the gameplay? Let's give the player every ability we can think of! And make her/him use them simultaneously during a very difficult gameplay!”  I bet at some point of the development, the creators of games like that think they are smart, and creative. Throwing every idea for a gameplay element in to the final product, redrawing jokes made by others and making obvious references to other games...  P.S. Of course the level of difficulty is not only to be blamed on the controller. The game is literally unfair. Exactly like playing a badly designed NES game. UNFAIR. The projectiles thrown by enemies go right through every element of the environment, every enemy and stop only at the player. Every enemy attack is impossible to block and usually it has priority over your attack even if it is a combo, or a special move. Also, some actions work in some cases, and don't work in other (in which logic tells you, they should). The controls feel very awkward generaly, and most actions are hard to trigger.

Charming and with a lot of style in every way.  I would gladly recommend this game if you are a semi-hardcore or more platformer.  However for everybody else, be fairly warned,  The game has a tendency to have one or two basic ideas (world switch and color shields) and then mercilessly repeat them again and again and again and ... absolutely endlessly again ... in ever more cumbersome ways, which is it way of adding content and 'difficulty'.  It becomes painful over time and in some ways punishing.  Add to this that it also creeps into fights (color shields, warp between worlds, white shields, bombs, bombs with shield .. you get the idea) and it becomes mindnumbing.  Also if you do not own a controller save your self some headaches and pass on this game. It is excruciating without one as the keyboard setup sadly makes the above even worse.  Frankly, the game badly needs a bye option where it lets you pass after a certain amount of attempts or deaths, to appeal to a larger crowd and not to mention provide more entertainment and less annoyance.
I would love to recommend this game for the lovely art style and metroid style gameplay but the brutal difficulty spikes that come out of no where suck the fun out of the game,

Really not what I had hoped for or expected. The only game in my steam library I regret buying.  The Good: This game is unique in that it is to my knowledge the only 2D Mexican-themed metroidvania beat-em-up in existence. For the first 1/3 of the game, you'll be thinking 'wow, I've never played anything quite like this'. Almost everything meshes really tightly (more on that 'almost' later).  Superficially, the game is great. I am usually critical of vector/Flash art in indie games (Ed McMillan's style is ugly and unappealing to me) but this game's style is beyond well done and beautifully drawn. It really captures the luchador aesthetic, and it's refreshing to see an indie game with an art style that isn't pixel art (or Ed McMillan's John K-esque gross-out shock-art style). One aspect of this game's art that really impressed me was that it uses its bold and flamboyant colour palette to its advantage: not only do the colours highlight the setting and theme, but bright and vivid contrasts make it very easy to not lose track of your character in the brawls, even in multiplayer. A++ to the art department. Colour me impressed.  The Bad: This game's music is repetitive and unmemorable. While what there is sounds very authentic and fitting, this is a game whose music will become muted very, very quickly. It feels there should be more, but there just… isn’t.  Unfortunately, beneath its shiny exterior Guacamelee! sports some very flawed game mechanics. Fighting becomes bland quickly, and about 1/3 of the way through things start to get baaad. The game tries to stave off the samey-samey-ness of the combat in ways that ultimately fall flat. Instead of increasing the (very limited) variety of enemies, the game introduces gimmicky limitations to combat that feel broken, frustratingly arbitrary, and poorly thought-out with respect to the way the characters control. They also artificially increase the difficulty to levels that border the “completely unfair / broken game design” line.  A fair challenge tests mastery of game mechanics and rewards player skill. Fair challenges are not a part of the latter 2/3 of this game. In fact, some parts of this game are so stupidly difficult (the insta-death fast-spawning exploding bomb enemies for example) that I almost stopped playing. These parts of the game do not test skill; they test patience (in the worst way) and temper. Failure during these parts is almost entirely out of player control. And I do mean literally out of player control because there is virtually no damage-invincibility or ability to recover from a mistake before your character becomes a pingpong ball. And this will happen, again and again and again…  The Ugly: Good writing can be to bad game design as is brown sugar to porridge. It can make something bland into something modestly enjoyable. Unfortunately, Guacamelee!’s writing is more like finding a hair in that bowl of porridge. Sure, it might be your own hair, so there's nothing wrong with it per se, but now you really don’t want to eat any more of that porridge because ewww.  Outside of combat, this game’s story is overrun by a certain style of humour. Take a long sigh out of your nose. That's really the best summary. There are a few actual jokes (setup/payoff) that did make me laugh. Unfortunately they are buried in a sea of dated and cringe-worthy internet memes (???), 'references' to movies, and 'call-outs' to popular videogames. Yes, that last sentence did indeed say “memes', as in 'injokes' with no purpose or amusing qualities beyond 'hey I know what that is lololol'.   Finally, the ending is an absolute joke.  And when I say the ending is an absolute joke, I mean both that it is an out-of-nowhere, context-blind, poorly-integrated reference, and also that it is abrupt, stupid, and ultimately unsatisfying.  Conclusion: I really wanted to recommend this game. After playing, I felt let-down and disappointed. Give it a pass.

I love the art and humor of this game, and the initial metroid style gameplay is fun. However, I can't recommend this unless you are the type of gamer who enjoys both memorizing long strings of combos, and extreme twitch platforming (think super meat boy with fighting game combos). Without an easier gameplay setting, the initial fun wears off quickly. If you are a masochist who loves dying over and over and over again on the same part, this game is for you.

Having seen two of my friends finish this game,I thought maybe I had been too harsh in my assessment of the product. Turns out I was right to begin with. The first level is nothing but running back and forth, holding stupid conversations with the locals and jumping up and down while punching some barrels. WOW. Mario has been there and done that already. Then all of a sudden you are dead and there are no clues as to what that giant green sparkly thing in the floor is and can I go back and do something with it? OOPS, no I guess not! Or why am I being attacked by skeletal Mexicans in ponchos and sombreros and why, why, WHY?   I probably have less than an hour in this game and was hoping for more but I found the story to be flat and without real substance and the gameplay to be less than fun (for me, anyway). The colours are nice, and the game appears to be professionally developed but that being said I am glad I only paid $3.00 for this game. Only buy this game if you truly enjoy twitch action side scrolling platformers with repetitive action. Otherwise save your cash. 3/10

This is exactly the sort of game that I usually enjoy, and yet it rubs me the wrong way at every opportunity.  The play mechanics are too stiff, so movement and combat just don't feel fun. When fighting, moves can be utilized in concert to air juggle, to maintain long combos, and to throw enemies at one another, but there really isn't any incentive to use these advanced techniques or even to vary attacks at all.  Then there's the Metroid structure, which is too condensed—too simple, too transparent, and too predictable. You're driven along a very narrow path of progression, and along the way you come across obvious markers for places you'll be able to enter once you receive the proper abilities. It's just by-the-numbers, and being teased by these blocked-off side paths feels rote when it should feel exciting. All of the game's puzzle-platforming challenges are characterized by the same workmanlike effort, too.  All of this would be disappointing although perhaps not damning, but Guacamelee wears this constant, unfading caca-eating grin that the writing absolutely does not earn. Many games love to wink at the player, but this one does it while standing over you in an arrogant pose. The most egregious example I've come across was a hidden QR code. I posted a screenshot complaining about how presumptuous and frustrating its inclusion is since I don't own any device capable of reading it, and a friend told me that it says 'Congratulations! You successfully identified and scanned a QR code! Great job!' That's it. That's the kind of reward you can expect for making the effort to discover secret paths.  I wish this game was a person so I could punch it in its stupid face.

Guacamelee! is advertised as a member of the 'Metroidvania' genre, which is largely what drove me to it. It draws on some of the key features of its heritage (accumulation of abilities which open paths and expose secrets) while departing from others (extended exploration, moody atmosphere, isolation). The story, while basic, is overbearing (compared to ancestors of the genre); there are a lot of monologues and cutscenes that probably aren't necessary––they're largely used for jokes. Icons like Super Metroid or Castlevania: Symphony of the Night give broad goals (reach Evil Guy X at the end) and let you work out everything inbetween. Guacamelee! repeatedly says 'go here on the map' with small rewards for deviating. But this is a hallmark of modern games, largely.  Like other reviewers have said, this is more of a brawler-platformer. It will appeal to fans of that type of game. The platforming becomes grueling at times, especially if you're using a keyboard. Don't believe other reviews that say it's unplayable with a keyboard; you'll just have to take a break every 45 minutes when your tendons start to hurt.  This is a weak Metroidvania title but a decent brawler-platformer. If you, like me, are/were expecting the former, you're liable to be disappointed.
